He just defined what the natural log is. It's the logarithm (inverse of a normal exponential) with this mystery base e. It's not a jumbled mess. It's pretty clear that you don't understand it. I have answered all of your questions in this comments section for that reason
By the definition of e. We defined M(a) = d(a^x)/dx with x=0. And we defined the number e as the value of a for which the curve of a^x has slope 1 in x=0. Hence, M(e) = slope of e^x with x=0 = 1

We assume the existence of such a number. And we can figure out what this number is from d/dx e^x = e^x (the famous infinite series ideology) which will give you 2.71828... That's why he said that he was "begging the question".

1. e isn't a natural number.   2. He did prove the existence of e by showing that when you stretch the function by a factor of k = 1/m(a), a^k = e. Since, m(a) exists, 1/m(a) also exists.   3. He then described the natural log as the inverse function of e^x and found its derivative. Then, using this result, he differentiated the original function a^x.   I had a similar thought while watching it for the first time. But following along by deriving on paper made it very clear. He did mention that it was a 'circuitous' method to find the derivative. M(e) equals 1 because he simply defined it that way.   In the lecture, he said that to find the value of M(a), we have to "beg the question" which means "to assume the truth of the conclusion."  In that sense, he assumed dy/dx(a^x)=(a^x)(M(a)) simply to be true even when he hasn't proved it yet. After some substitution, we find that equating M(e) to 1 is convenient since dy/dx(e^x)=e^x.   Now, the next step here is to prove if a number e exists such that M(e)=1 and such that dy/dx(e^x)=e^x. Otherwise, if e didn't exist, his initial definition M(e)=1 would be invalid.   But, at around 18:40, he does prove that such a number exists (although we don't know what it actually is yet).   Therefore, M(e) equals 1 at some number e.   ----  I hope this helped!

But for derivative of 2^kx at x=0 should be k M(2^k) ?

@chowdhury_kamruzzaman  He's not taken the derivative of b^x in the same way that he did for a^x in the beginning. b^x = f(kx)  Therefore, d/dx b^x = kf'(kx) (Chain rule) At x=0, kf'(kx) = kf'(0) Remember that f'(0) is M(2) (the slope of the original function 2^x at x = 0) Therefore, kf'(0) = kM(2) When b=e, the slope should be 1. That means that kM(2) should be 1. Therefore, k = 1/M(2). I believe there is a proof that M(a) is non-zero but that's not required here

That is exactly the question I have. I think the Professor has excellent credentials, but he has bullshitted his way here. People are just showering him with praises because he is at MIT. I think the following steps should follow: d/dx (b^x) = (b^x) * M(b). Hence d/dx (2^k)^x  =  ((2^k)^x) * M (2^k)

@jaredklements729  At x=0, what Prof Jerison has written is correct. You guys have written the derivative of b^x in the same manner as the derivative of a^x that we wrote in the beginning (with the M(a) function). That's why you guys have M(b) terms while Prof Jerison doesn't. He has replaced b^x with f(kx) whose derivative is kf'(kx).  f'(kx) at x=0 is f'(k*0) = f'(0). That is the derivative of the original function 2^x at x=0, which is M(2).

First, let y=f(kx) and u=kx. This makes y=f(u). Then deploy chain rule so: --- dy/dx = (dy/du).(du/dx). Now compute the derivatives du/dx = k and dy/du = f'(u) Therefore, y' = k f'(u) substitute back in u=kx. This gives - y' = k f(kx). Hope this helps. : )

There are three typographical errors on the notes that I just want to point out, in Fig. 3. The scant line from (-1/2,1/2) to (0,1)  in the notes it says (1,0). If you work out the slope (y2-y1/(x2-x1) it comes out right if the points are (-1/2,1/2) and (0,1) The same error is repeated in the actual figure, the y-intercept should be (0,1) and not (1,0) The last typo is on page 4 in a both in the center it say e^x = w it should read e^w =x as is correctly expressed 5 lines after.

His goal is to find the derivative of ln x which is w. At that case, derivative of ln x is unknown but can be found by using the fact that we know the derivative of e^x (which he found earlier). By taking exponential, he gets rid of the lnx whose derivative is not known and applies chain rule to find d ln x/ dx.

I know this is 5 years late, but it's because you need to understand that kx is a function. There are two functions here:  y = f(kx) z = kx  So what we want to solve is: y'(z) With the chain rule that is: y'(z)z'  We don't know what y' is yet, so we'll just say the y' = f'(kx) We DO know what z' is: z' = k That's because k is a constant while x is variable.  So that leaves that: f'(kx) = k f'(kx)

Single variable calculus (aka Calculus I and II) is equivalent to AP Calc AB and BC.  In AB, there is material from Calc I and a bit from Calc II. In BC, the material revisits Calc I to some extent (that's why there's a B in the course names AB and BC) and then covers the Calc II material.   Calculus III (multivariable) is not covered in high school because most students don't reach that far (the ones that do might take a special class or they enroll in a college class while in high school).
